abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Primary Education
            Quality Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: a) Considering
            the political and administrative context of projects is
            important in order to minimize the risks of transition or
            administration changes. b) It is important to develop an
            evaluation culture among staff at different levels. c) There
            is a need to focus on the school autonomy concept in an
            operational way. d) To achieve a better integration of the
            various components during implementation, it would have been
            necessary to rely on gradual interventions and pilot
            experiences. e) The quality of training institutions and
            programs needs to be improved. f) This project is able to
            finance the quality improvement component with not just Bank
            funding, but also national counterpart funds. g) The absence
            of a single authority in charge of defining and implementing
            education policies and regulations for the entire education
            system hinders the proper function of the system. h)
            Stronger supervision and monitoring mechanisms are needed to
            ensure that the project design and objectives are adhered to
            during the project implementation.

18225180.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Primary
            Education Quality Project are to improve teaching conditions
            within primary school classrooms; strengthen public school
            management; improve the planning monitoring and management
            capacity of central, departmental and local education
            authorities; and improve educational infrastructure. The
            project will also attempt to increase the educational
            systems' equity by ensuring that priority is given in
            all activities to poor urban and rural areas. The project is
            comprised of three components. The first is an educational
            quality component, which will support improvements in the
            availability of textbooks and instructional materials,
            competencies of primary school teachers, and curriculum
            scope, sequence and adaptability. The second component is a
            modernization of educational administration which will
            strengthen the management capacity of the education sector
            at all levels, implement and reform existing budgetary and
            management functions, develop information management
            capabilities, and establish a modern student assessment
            system. The third is an infrastructure improvement component
            to support the improvement of teaching and learning
            conditions by rehabilitating and replacing primary school
            infrastructure in rural and urban poor areas.
